institution-wrap.institution: Department of Psychology, University of Wisconsin-Madison

abstract.p: This study found some pretty cool results that have both high impact and important clinical implications. For example …

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: You can write your text using markdown.
Top level section headings use ##

sec.title: Sub-heading Demo
sec.p: You can use sub-headings in your paper as well

sec.title: Symbols and Equations
sec.p: You can use quarto inline or display math equations as needed. Quarto provides details on the use of these equations.
For example x x and y y are two variables. And here is an important formula:

sec.title: Data Figures
sec.p: Figures are also generally created in separate notebooks and embedded into your manuscript.

sec.title: References
sec.p: We can use cite relevant research in multiple formats. The two most common are:
Article references are stored in a .bib file using betterbibtex (BBT) format. We create these references in Zotero collections.
Although we don’t do this regularly I think, if needed you can reference figures elsewhere using the @ symbol. Here is a reference to Figure 1

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: To add results that are not figures or tables, you will need to open the objects you saved from these analyses. See lm.qmd as an example. Generally you will open csv files that contain tidied results. For example
A significant effect of speed was observed ( \beta β = 3.9, t = 9.46, p = 0.000).
NOTES:

list-item.p: We should write a function that works with tidied coeffs tables and takes the row, column, and number of decimal places to make this code simpler.
This table doesnt contain df. Need to add that to table when saving in lm

body.p: Fit the lm to our data

sec.code: m <- lm (dist ~ speed, data = cars) summary(m)

# Tidied version of coeffs table is preferred over summary for saving. # Its a tibble with better names for columns! # NOTE: Need to add df column to this table for results reporting. Can pull from summary(m) (coeff_table <- broom::tidy(m))

sec.preformat:
Call: lm(formula = dist ~ speed, data = cars)
Residuals: Min 1Q Median 3Q Max -29.069 -9.525 -2.272 9.215 43.201
Coefficients: Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) (Intercept) -17.5791 6.7584 -2.601 0.0123 * speed 3.9324 0.4155 9.464 1.49e-12 *** --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
Residual standard error: 15.38 on 48 degrees of freedom Multiple R-squared: 0.6511, Adjusted R-squared: 0.6438 F-statistic: 89.57 on 1 and 48 DF, p-value: 1.49e-12
# A tibble: 2 × 5 term estimate std.error statistic p.value <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> 1 (Intercept) -17.6 6.76 -2.60 1.23e- 2 2 speed 3.93 0.416 9.46 1.49e-12

body.p: Save the model to load and use in manuscript results section. Consider what should be saved. We might save the model object because you can get everything you need from it. But better still might be to save the output you need (e.g., tibble of coefficients and test statistics). In this example, we save both for the lm as demonstrations.

list-item.p: If saving the model object, note that some models from tidymodels (e.g., keras, maybe xgboost) may need special procedure for saving.

sec.code:
# can save tidied tables of results as csv. This is preferred method for saving tables and we believe that saving the tables is likely the best choice for later access to results in index.qmd coeff_table |> write_csv(here::here("./notebooks/objects", "coeff_table.csv"))
# There may be situations where you need access to the model itself in index.qmd. If so, model objects should be saved with saveRDS() m |> saveRDS(here::here("./notebooks/objects", "lm.rds"))
